quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Elasticity Applications & Consumer Choice
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Price Elasticity of Supply, Utility Maximization, Budget Constraints, Elasticity Determinants, Tax Incidence

questions.question: Which of the following factors would make the demand for a good more elastic?
options: The time period considered is very short
The good represents a small portion of consumers' budgets
questions.explanation: Demand is more elastic when there are **many close substitutes** (consumers can easily switch). Necessities, short time periods, and small budget shares tend to make demand more inelastic.

questions.question: If a consumer spends all their income on two goods, X and Y, and the price of X falls, what happens to the budget constraint?
options: It shifts outward in a parallel fashion
It pivots outward along the X‑axis
It shifts inward along the Y‑axis
questions.explanation: A decrease in the price of good X increases the maximum quantity of X affordable (if all income is spent on X) → budget line **pivots outward along the X‑axis**, slope = –Px/Py becomes flatter.

questions.question: A tax is imposed on a good with perfectly inelastic demand. Who bears the burden of the tax?
questions.explanation: Perfectly inelastic demand → quantity demanded does not change when price changes. Sellers can pass the full tax to buyers via higher prices → **consumers bear the full tax burden**.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of supply is 0.8, a 10% increase in price will lead to a:
questions.explanation: Price elasticity of supply = %∆Qs / %∆P. Given Es = 0.8 and %∆P = 10%, %∆Qs = 0.8 × 10% = **8% increase**.

questions.question: A consumer maximizes utility when:
options: Marginal utility per dollar spent is equal for all goods
The budget constraint is tangent to the highest possible indifference curve
questions.explanation: Utility is maximized when **MUX/PX = MUY/PY** (equal marginal utility per dollar) **and** the chosen bundle lies on the budget line tangent to the highest indifference curve.

questions.question: If demand is unit elastic, a price increase will cause total revenue to:
questions.explanation: Unit elastic demand (|Ed| = 1) → %∆Qd = %∆P → total revenue remains unchanged when price changes.

questions.question: Which scenario describes a Giffen good?
questions.explanation: A **Giffen good** is an inferior good for which the income effect outweighs the substitution effect, leading to an upward‑sloping demand curve: **quantity demanded rises when price rises**.

questions.question: If the cross‑price elasticity between coffee and tea is +0.3, and the price of coffee rises by 20%, what happens to the quantity demanded of tea?
questions.explanation: Cross‑price elasticity = %∆Qd of tea / %∆P of coffee. +0.3 = %∆Qd / 20% → %∆Qd = 0.3 × 20% = **6% increase** (substitutes).

questions.question: The price of movie tickets rises from \$10 to \$12, and quantity demanded falls from 200 to 160. Using the midpoint formula, what is the price elasticity of demand?
If a good accounts for a very small portion of a consumer’s budget, demand for that good is likely to be:
questions.explanation: When a good represents a **small budget share**, consumers are less responsive to price changes → demand tends to be **inelastic**.

scoreMessages.70: Good understanding; review midpoint elasticity calculations, Giffen goods, and the utility maximization condition (MU/P equalization).
scoreMessages.50: Basics present; work on: 1) Midpoint formula, 2) Price elasticity of supply calculations, 3) Cross‑price elasticity applications, 4) Budget constraint shifts.
